The consequences of not giving up the fi: A mendicant who has feeble and weak wisdom
They would not know what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both
They would not realize any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones
The consequences of giving up the five o: A mendicant who has powerful wisdom
They would know what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both
They would realize any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones
The simile of the mountain river (a caus: A man would open channels on both sides
The mid-river current would be dispersed, spread out, and separated
The river would no longer flow swiftly, going far, carrying all before it
The simile of the mountain river (contin: A man would close up the channels on both sides
The mid-river current would not be dispersed, spread out, and separated
The river would keep flowing swiftly for a long way, carrying all before it.
